bestBHT.bht: As Christian soldiers, we are called to be ready for any challenge or suffering that God wills. To do so, our feet are to be shod with the readiness of the Gospel of Peace. This readiness, derived from the peace that comes through the gospel, equips us to face the conflicts and challenges of life. By being prepared with the gospel, our feet are securely planted on a firm foundation, guiding us in our every step and enabling us to stand firm in our faith.

Henry Alford: and having shod your feet...with the readiness of the Gospel of Peace.
The Roman caliga, or soldier's buskin, may be in the Apostle's mind.
The Gospel whose message and spirit is peace.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Having shod your feet" (referring to the sandals, or to the military shoes then used).
Preparedness to do and suffer all that God wills; readiness for march, as a Christian soldier.
The 'peace' within forms a beautiful contrast to the raging of the outward conflict.
Albert Barnes: The Christian soldier is to be prepared with the gospel of peace to meet attacks similar to those against which the ancient soldier designed to guard himself by the sandals or greaves which he wore.
The word rendered 'preparation' - (ἑτοιμασία hetoimasia) - means properly readiness, fitness for, alacrity.

Christians were to have the principles of the gospel of peace - the peaceful and pure gospel - to facilitate them; to aid them in their marches; to make them firm in the day of conflict with their foes.
Marvin Vincent: Preparation [ετοιμασια] . Only here in the New Testament.
The Roman soldier substituted for the greaves of the Greek (metal plates covering the lower part of the leg) the caligae or sandals.
Etoimasia means readiness; but in Hellenistic Greek it was sometimes used in the sense of establishment or firm foundation, which would suit this passage: firm - footing.
John Calvin: We must be shod with the gospel, if we would pass unhurt through the world.
It is the gospel of peace, and it is so called, as every reader must perceive, from its effects; for it is the message of our reconciliation to God, and nothing else gives peace to the conscience.
Paul holds out the gospel as the fittest means for undertaking and performing the expedition.
Philip Schaff: The Roman soldier wore sandals, in the soles of which nails were thickly studded, to give firm footing. Doubtless Paul had this in mind.
This ‘preparedness’ is more than a natural readiness or courage, it comes from the gospel of peace, the gospel whose contents are peace with God.
Peaceableness toward men is not excluded; but there is no reference to readiness to preach the gospel. That is the aggressive, not the defensive part, of our duty.
Archibald T. Robertson: First aorist middle participle of υποδεω, old word, to bind under.
Readiness of mind that comes from the gospel whose message is peace.
John Gill: The Gospel is so called, because it makes men to be of peaceable tempers and behaviour, and gives peace to distressed minds.

The preparation of [the Gospel]...designs a firm and solid knowledge of the Gospel, as it publishes peace by Jesus Christ, which yields a sure foundation for the Christian soldier to set his foot upon, and stand fast on.

It [shodding the feet with the Gospel] designs the constant and firm standing of believers in the faith of the Gospel, and so striving and contending for it, without being moved from it, that it may continue with them.
John Wesley: And your feet shod with the preparation of the gospel — Let this be always ready to direct and confirm you in every step.
Our feet must be so shod, that our footsteps slip not.
To order our life and conversation aright, we are prepared by the gospel blessing, the peace and love of God ruling in the heart.

bhtAttempts.bht: As Christians, we are called to be like soldiers, ready to do and suffer all that God wills. In Ephesians 6:15, Paul instructs us to shod our feet with the readiness of the Gospel of Peace. Just as Roman soldiers wore sandals or military shoes for firm footing, we are to be firmly grounded in the gospel message of peace. This readiness of mind, derived from the peace that comes through the gospel, equips us to face the conflicts and challenges of life. The gospel not only brings peace within ourselves, but also allows us to be of peaceful temper and behavior towards others. By being prepared with the gospel, our feet are securely planted on a firm foundation, guiding us in our every step and enabling us to stand fast in our faith.

This readiness and firm foundation, derived from the gospel, equips us to face the conflicts of life. By being prepared with the gospel, our feet are firmly planted, guiding our every step and enabling us to stand fast in our faith. The gospel message of peace brings inner peace and directs our actions towards others in a peaceful manner.
